title: What is racialization
body:
A note about terminology: When describing people collectively, it is currently recommended to use the term “racialized person” or “racialized group”. This is widely preferred over “racial minority”, “visible minority”, “person of colour” or “non-White”. Doing so reflects race as a social construct rather than being based in biological facts.

“Racialization” is the process by which people come to be designated as being of a particular "race". A person is racialized based on their physical features or other personal characteristics. Deep rooted beliefs in society have associated negative stereotypes with these characteristics – this has led to disadvantages for people with these traits.

Racism is a historical and current reality for Indigenous Peoples in Canada, and Indigenous people are also racialized. However, due to their unique political and historical experiences they are not referred to as racialized communities. As a distinct and separate communities, Indigenous Peoples in Canada can be identified as “First Nations”, “Métis”, “Inuit” or “Indigenous Peoples”.

[Reference: 16]

title: What is the link between race and privilege?
displayTitle: What is the link between race and privilege?
body:
Racism is entrenched in many of society’s systems and institutions. Over time, it has led to members of the dominant group having built-in advantages and opportunities that are not experienced by people who are racialized or Indigenous: these advantages are referred to as privilege. Many people are unaware of them. The following statements are helpful in understanding how experiences can differ based on privilege.

[References: 5, 18]
instruction: Select each person to learn more.

_graphic.alt: Group of four White people with neutral expressions.

_items.body: I am more likely to see positive portrayals of people who look like me on the news, on TV shows and in movies
I can travel with my spouse who is racialized, and not expect to be questioned about our relationship when crossing the border
When I use cheques or credit cards, my skin tone will not be a reason people hesitate to trust my credit or financial responsibility
If I make a mistake or demonstrate a personal failing, this will likely not be used to later deny opportunities or compassion to people who share my racial or Indigenous identity

instruction: Which of the following statements is correct?

_items.text: A) The concept of race is founded in biology.
B) You can tell a person's race by looking at their DNA.
C) Race as a concept has been in existence throughout human history.
D) Race is a concept developed by society to marginalize people, and has been applied in various ways in different parts of the world and throughout history.

title: Question 4
body: An Indigenous woman is pulled over by a law enforcement officer when driving her new Lexus. She is questioned about her car, and asked how she was able to afford it.
instruction: Could this be a case of racial profiling?

_items.text: No. The officers could be acting based on reasonable suspicion or conducting a random check.

Yes. Although the stop could be random, the questions asked could be interpreted as inferring that the driver could not be in a position to afford the car based on her identity. This could indicate that negative stereotypes are influencing the officer's decision. This has been identified by the courts as an indicator of racial profiling.

_feedback.correct:
Correct!

Other possible indicators of racial profiling indicated by the courts include:

  • Contradictory or changing explanations, or irrelevant reasons for differential treatment
  • Differences in how the situation unfolded when the person involved was White
  • Deviations from normal practice
  • Use of an unprofessional manner or discourteous treatment

title: What is race?
body:
In our job as BSOs, we serve travellers from a range of backgrounds. In doing so, we are committed to providing conscientious and equitable service to every person, regardless of the range of personal characteristics, including race. But have you ever stopped to think about what “race” really means?

[References: 3, 17]
instruction: Click each statement to learn about race.

_items.front:
Scientists can determine a person's race by looking at their DNA.


True or False?

back.title: False
back.body: There is no gene for "race". Genetically, humans are 99.9% identical. Of this tiny variation, 85% happens within so called “races” - such as Polish or Hmong people - rather than between them. Two Korean people are likely to be as genetically different as a Korean and an Italian.

_items.front:
Race is a modern idea.


True or False?

back.title: True
back.body: In ancient societies, religion, status, class or even language distinctions were more important than physical appearance. Race emerged at the time of European empire-building in the 17th century. The success of these ventures depended on the ideology of the superiority of white-skinned people to justify the enslavement and dispossession of non-white and Indigenous Peoples.

_items.front:
Race refers only to skin colour.


True or False?

back.title: False
back.body: Race is often used to refer to a group of people who have some visible physical traits in common, such as skin colour or hair texture. Reflecting its purpose as a tool to marginalize people, however, it has been applied in various ways in different parts of the world and throughout history. It has been used to refer to linguistic groups (the “Arab race”), to religious groups (the “Jewish race”), and even to political, national, or ethnic groups with few characteristics that distinguish them from their neighbours (the “Irish race”).

_items.front:
A person’s skin colour can predict their cultural or personal identity.


True or False?

back.title: False
back.body: Most traits are governed by different genes, so they're inherited independently. Physical traits tell us nothing about a person’s behaviours, preferences, or abilities.

_items.front:
Race is not biological; therefore, we should be “colour-blind”.


True or False?

back.title: False
back.body: It is true that biological notions of race have been discredited. However, it is critical to recognize the significance of race on a person’s experiences in society. The social meanings attached to physical differences, can lead to a person experiencing unfair or differential treatment.

body: Differing from criminal profiling, racial profiling is based on stereotypical assumptions based on one's race, colour, national or ethnic origin or religion, resulting in adverse treatment. How can a BSO ensure any profiling conducted is non-discriminatory?

_items.feedback: Incorrect - It is acceptable to refer to an individual’s race, colour, national or ethnic origin or religion as part of a specific traveller description when there is a reasonable suspicion based on a multiplicity of indicators.

_items.text: Both are effective tools for uncovering criminal activity, so no action is needed.
_items.feedback: Incorrect - Criminal profiling focuses on behavioural profiles, rather than using race as a determining factor. title: Is racial profiling the same as criminal profiling?
displayTitle: Is racial profiling the same as criminal profiling?
body: Racial profiling should not be confused with criminal profiling - they are two different things with different approaches, legal obligations and impacts.
instruction: Select each tab to view the details

_items.title: Racial profiling:
_items.body:
• Is based on stereotypical assumptions because of one’s race, colour, national or ethnic origin, or religion
  • It subjects targeted individuals to different treatment and/or greater scrutiny than others
  • It is not acceptable at the CBSA

_items.title: Criminal profiling:
_items.body:
• Relies on actual behaviour
  • Relies on information about suspected activity by someone who meets the description of a specific individual 
  • It is an objective, evidence-based tool used within the law enforcement that can provide insight into the unknown offender

title: Identifying racial profiling: Examples from case law
displayTitle: Identifying racial profiling: Examples from case law
body: There is a growing body of provincial and federal case law that has found racial profiling across various sectors of Canadian society.  Here are some recent examples from law enforcement agencies where race was a factor in the decision to detain, search or investigate an individual.  Review each one to gain insights into what racial profiling looks like and how it can happen, to help us prevent it at the CBSA.
instruction: Select each example to learn more.

_graphic.alt: A person cycling a bike at night

_items.title: Case law: Street check tainted by discriminatory arrest of an Indigenous man
_items.body:
McKay v Toronto Police Services Board 

Mr. McKay, an Indigenous man, and his friend were stopped in a laneway in Little Italy in Toronto at around 4:30 am by a Toronto Police officer. They had been delivering flyers. There were concerns about break and enters in the area. The officer followed Mr. McKay and his friend into the laneway, asked for identification and conducted a Canadian Police and Information Centre (or CPIC) check.

Despite CPIC clearance, the officer inquired further as to whether Mr. McKay’s bike was stolen. The officer refused to consider McKay’s explanation of the bike’s purchase, and arrested McKay for theft of the wrong bike based on incomplete and flawed information.

The situation: 

Mr. McKay, an Indigenous man, and his friend were stopped in a laneway in Little Italy in Toronto at around 4:30 am by a Toronto Police officer. 

The judgement: 

The Human Rights Tribunal of Ontario found that while the decision to follow Mr. McKay and his friend into the laneway, ask for identification and conduct the check were not appropriate, the following actions were discriminatory:

  • The decision to further investigate was driven by negative stereotypes of Indigenous Peoples
  • The refusal to consider the explanation of the bike’s purchase was based on a hunch – the officer perceived a disconnect between the dishevelled appearance of Mr. McKay and their having an “expensive looking bike”
  • The arrest was based on incomplete and flawed information
  • Over-scrutiny occurred, even through there were no concerns about any outstanding charges, and McKay was not behaving suspiciously

Learnings from this case: 

Racial profiling:

  • can affect how people continue to deal with each other after an initial encounter
  • can be a product of stereotypes about Indigenous Peoples
  • can be exhibited through over-policing of Indigenous Peoples

A hunch based on intuition gained by experience is not a credible non-discriminatory explanation for adverse treatment

[McKay v. Toronto Police Services Board, 2011 HRTO 499]

_graphic.alt: The interior of a shopping mall

_items.title: Case law: More intensive investigation into shop-lifting allegation based on shopper’s race
_items.body:
Nassiah v Peel (Regional Municipality) Services Board 

The situation: 

Peel Police were contacted to investigate a possible shop-lifting incident at a local mall. Ms. Nassiah, a Black woman, was stopped by security when leaving a large department store. Ms. Nassiah was accused of stealing an item of clothing with a value of under $10. Ms Nassiah repeatedly denied the allegation, even volunteering to be searched by staff in the washroom. The officer on the case questioned if she could speak English, and refused to look at all the evidence, including a security tape, after assuming that the White security guard was telling the truth. The officer ordered a second body search after the first had already failed to find anything. The police and store security ultimately released Ms. Nassiah after they concluded that they had made an error.

The judgement: 

The Human Rights Tribunal of Ontario found discriminatory treatment based on:

  • Stereotypically assuming that a Black suspect might not speak English
  • Assuming that the White security guard was telling the truth, without properly looking at all the evidence
  • Adopting an “assumption of guilt” approach to the investigation
  • Arranging for a second body search after the first one did not uncover the allegedly stolen item
  • Continuing with the investigation, even after the second body search confirmed that they did not have the stolen item
  • Subjecting Ms. Nassiah to verbal abuse, and threatening to take them to jail    

Learnings from this case:

Racial profiling:

  • can affect how people continue to deal with each other after an initial encounter
  • can be a product of stereotypes about African Canadians 
  • is a systemic issue in policing

[Nassiah v. Peel (Regional Municipality) Services Board, 2007 HRTO 14]

_items.title: Case law: Discriminatory stop of driver based on race
_items.body:
Johnson v Halifax (Regional Municipality) Police Service 

The situation: 

Two Black men in a Texas-registered black Ford Mustang were pursued and stopped by a Halifax Police Constable. The Constable had slowed down sharply, allowed the car to pass, then followed and stopped the car. The Constable asked for proof of insurance and vehicle registration but did not accept the validity of the documents offered. The officer also refused to permit Mr. Johnson, the owner of the car, to explain the documentation and what was required in Texas.

The officer ticketed Mr. Johnson, and ordered the car towed. In fact, the documentation was valid under Texas law. The seizure was erroneous, and the car was released the following day.

The judgement: 

The Nova Scotia Human Rights Commission's Board of Inquiry found discrimination as:

  • the Constable’s actions were influenced by a racial stereotypes
  • the situation would likely have unfolded differently if the individuals had been White

Learnings from this case: 

Racial profiling: 

  • can be a product of stereotypes about African-Canadians
  • need not be main cause of adverse treatment
  • can happen if the person alleged to have profiled had an opportunity to observe the person's race
  • can be indicated by deviations from normal practice, or the use of an unprofessional manner

If a person experiences (or perceives) racial profiling, the officer must handle any abusive language by the person with reasonable tolerance and tact, and cannot discriminate further

[Johnson v. Halifax (Regional Municipality) Police Service, 2005 NSCA 70]

_items.title: Case law: Discriminatory assault, search and restraint during a street check based on race
_items.body:
Elmardy v Toronto (City) Police Services Board 

The situation: 

Mr. Elmardy, a Black man, was stopped by two Toronto police officers while walking home from prayers one night in January. The officers suspected that Mr. Elmardy was violating bail terms by walking alone, and that Mr. Elmardy potentially had a weapon because their hands were in their pockets. Mr. Elmardy did not have any gloves and it was cold outside. When Mr. Elmardy refused to take their hands out of their pockets, they were punched in the face twice by the officers. The officers emptied Mr. Elmardy’s pockets and handcuffed the man, leaving the man’s hands exposed to the cold for about 20 minutes. Mr. Elmardy was not charged with any offence.

The judgement: 

The Superior Court of Ontario found that: 

  • there was no reasonable basis for the stop
  • the search was a breach of rights under the Charter of Rights and Freedoms

On appeal, the Divisional Court also found that the officers discriminated based on race by:

  • Suspecting Mr. Elmardy based on unconscious or conscious beliefs about Black men
  • Based on these unreasonable beliefs, assaulting, unreasonably searching and forcibly restraining Mr. Elmardy
  • Assuming and acting as if Mr. Elmardy was guilty and dangerous – leading to a violation of constitutional rights

Learnings from this case:

Racial profiling:

  • can be the product of unconscious or conscious beliefs about Black men
  • has a serious impact on the credibility and effectiveness of police services
  • can lead to public distrust, and must be stopped

[Elmardy v Toronto Police Services Board, 2017 ONSC 2074]

_graphic.alt: A woman outside in the winter with no gloves, attempting to warm up her hands.

_items.title: Case law: Discrimination based on race, age and sex at a border crossing
_items.body:
Davis v Canada Border Services Agency 

The situation: 

Ms. Davis, a young Mohawk woman was questioned by the CBSA officers upon returning from the US at a land border crossing. Ms. Davis alleged that the CBSA officers stopped them without warning and forced them to stand outside, without a coat, in -6-degree weather for 45 minutes. The CBSA claimed that Ms. Davis’s vehicle was selected as part of an operation to check whether certain vehicles contained secret compartments that could be used to move contraband goods. The Canadian Human Rights Tribunal did not find that Ms. Davis had been personally targeted for inspection, and questioned whether Ms. Davis had behaved appropriately when using foul language in addressing the officers. The court highlighted that some of the officers acted professionally in the face of Ms. Davis’s attitude, but that discrimination did occur.

The judgement: 

The Canadian Human Rights Tribunal found discrimination based on:

  • one of the officers raising their voice and responding in a manner that, if only unconsciously, resulted from racial stereotyping

Learnings from this case: 

Racial profiling can be indicated if:

  • deviations from normal practice and evidence of discourtesy are present
  • race, or another prohibited ground of discrimination, is one of the factors that led the person in authority to apply differential treatment

The authority present must demonstrate reasonable tolerance and tact towards the person reacting strongly

An inappropriate exercise of authority based on race is not justified, even if it results in identifying an illegal act

[Canada (Attorney General) v. Davis, 2017 FC 159]

title: What the law says about racial profiling:  Some highlights
displayTitle: What the law says about racial profiling:  Some highlights
body:
Here’s are some highlights of what the law says about racial profiling, based on cases handled across Canada in recent years. Where racial profiling was proven, courts have noted that it is not only contrary to fundamental human rights but is also unacceptable in law enforcement. 

[Reference: 10]

• stereotypes about Indigenous Peoples, African Canadians and Arabs and Muslims
  • stereotypes about criminality

_items.title: Can happen even if:

title: Learning objectives
body:
In this module you will learn about:

  • The unconscious processes in our brain that can lead to discriminatory actions or decisions
  • How unconscious biases can influence our decision-making
  • Ways to manage our biases to support conscious, consistent and bias-neutral application of BSO protocols

title: What is unconscious bias?
body:
Unconscious bias refers to the “social stereotypes about certain groups of people that individuals form outside their own conscious awareness” (University of California San Francisco’s Office of Diversity and Outreach).  

Our brain is hard-wired to help us make instant decisions. Without us being aware of it, and without our active involvement, it can influence the quality and accuracy of our understanding, actions and decisions. Nevertheless, with conscious effort and practice it can be managed for better, more objective decision-making.

[Reference: 22]
instruction: Select the pins to learn more

_graphic.alt: Illustration depicting the unconscious mind: an iceberg under water inside the outline of a person’s head

_items.title: How does unconscious bias work?
_items.body:
•  To navigate our complex world and make quick decisions, our brain takes mental shortcuts. -
  • We can process roughly 11 million bits of information every second; only 40–50 of these bits are handled by our conscious brain – the rest is done unconsciously.
  • Upon meeting someone, it takes us less than one second to categorize them by race and gender, and whether they are a member of our “ingroup”.
  • The issue is that our unconscious brain is influenced by stereotypes (both positive and negative) present in society about certain groups of people.
  • Stereotypes enable us to make rapid judgements when we have incomplete information – although sometimes based in part on fact, they tend to be inaccurate.
  • So, often, our gut reactions to a person or situation is based on faulty assumptions about their race, colour, national or ethnic origin, or religion, or other personal characteristics.

_items.title: Who has unconscious bias?
_items.body:
• Everyone has unconscious beliefs in one or more areas. 
  • They develop from early childhood, influenced over time by our background, education and messaging from the media, amongst other sources.
  • Unconscious bias is very often contrary to our conscious values and beliefs.

_items.title: What we can do about unconscious bias?
_items.body:
• We cannot completely eliminate our biases - they happen automatically without our active involvement.  
  • However, we can disrupt them and limit their effects by:
    • trying to recognize them
    • being alert in situations when they are more likely to arise
    • challenging them when they happen
_items.strapline: What we can do about unconscious bias?

title: What forms can unconscious bias take?
displayTitle: What forms can unconscious bias take?
body:
Unconscious bias can be demonstrated in a number of ways we interact with others.

Think back to the activity you completed at the start of this module – did you experience any of these types of bias when presented with the images of the various people?
instruction: Select each title to learn about some of these ways

_items.title: First Impressions Bias
_items.body:
Relying too heavily on the first piece of information acquired when making decisions about a person or situation.

Example: Doubting a person’s credibility based on the fact that they are wearing worn clothing.

_items.title: Ingroup Bias
_items.body:
Responding more positively to people from groups we identify with, rather than to people from other groups.

Example: Viewing in a more positive light a traveller who you identify with based on a shared characteristic – such as race, occupation, income level or other factor.

_items.title: Confirmation Bias
_items.body:
Favouring perspectives like our own, or seeking out information that validates a perspective we already have.

Example: Assuming that a person is not telling the truth, and then interpreting ambiguous evidence or recalling information selectively to support your initial belief.

_items.title: Stereotype Bias
_items.body:
Making assumptions based on stereotypes about a group of people.

Example: Thinking that it is “out of place” for a traveller to be carrying a large amount of cash, based on stereotypes about the socio-economic status of their demographic group.

title: Which situations can activate our unconscious bias?
displayTitle: Which situations can activate our unconscious bias?
body:
During a particularly busy day at work you might choose your “go-to” lunch at the cafeteria rather than trying something new. Similarly, in certain situations our brain will be more likely to activate our unconscious biases to fill in missing information.

We experience many of these situations as BSOs in our demanding jobs on the frontline. By anticipating that our unconscious biases may arise in such situations, we can prepare ourselves to disrupt them when they arise.

title: Unconscious bias in practice - examples from the research
displayTitle: Unconscious bias in practice - examples from the research
body:
Unconscious forms of discrimination are universal. Here are some examples of how it can affect our decision-making:

  • Police officers lower the speed on traffic tickets when the officer shares the same first name as the person being ticketed
  • Judges issue shorter sentences when defendants are sentenced on their birthdays
  • Job applicants with names of Indian, Pakistani, or Chinese origin are less likely to get called for an interview compared to applicants with traditionally Anglo names
  • In emergency rooms, White people are given stronger painkillers than Black or Hispanic patients

Can you think of some examples of how our unconscious biases can affect the decisions we make as BSOs? 

[References: 4, 8, 21]

title: How can unconscious bias lead to racial profiling?
displayTitle: How can unconscious bias lead to racial profiling?
body:
As we saw in module 2, Canadian courts have recognized that racial profiling is usually the result of beliefs, biases and prejudices that we are not even aware of.  Even the most well-intentioned, fair and inclusive individual can be influenced by stereotypes about another person based on their race, colour, national or ethnic origin, or religion. So what is going on in our brain that makes this happen?

Although people may hold an unconscious bias, it does not mean they agree with or should be defined by it. They may even be diametrically opposed to it.  However, it is important to note that even if you did not intend to treat someone differently, the outcome can be harmful and is still considered to be discrimination.
instruction: Review the following steps and put them in the correct order for how bias can lead to racial profiling.

_items.text: Differential treatment: These automatic associations can then, without us being conscious of it, influence how we react to and interact with this person, sometimes resulting in discriminatory behaviour
Unconscious bias: Our brain, over time, makes an unconscious automatic association between the group of people and the stereotype

Stereotype: Negative stereotypes are present in society about racialized or Indigenous Peoples (such as, criminality, trustworthiness, credibility or intelligence), which are reinforced by explicit or implicit messages from the media
Activating situation: Especially when in a new or unfamiliar situation, the unconscious bias can activate and we treat the individual as if they fit the stereotype

_feedback.title: Feedback
_feedback.correct:
You have identified the correct steps.

  1. Stereotype: Negative stereotypes are present in society about racialized or Indigenous Peoples (such as, criminality, trustworthiness, credibility or intelligence), which are reinforced by explicit or implicit messages from the media
  2. Unconscious bias: Our brain, over time, makes an unconscious automatic association between the group of people and the stereotype
  3. Activating situation: Especially when in a new or unfamiliar situation, the unconscious bias can activate and we treat the individual as if they fit the stereotype  
  4. Differential treatment: These automatic associations can then, without us being conscious of it, influence how we react to and interact with this person, sometimes resulting in discriminatory behaviour

_incorrect.final:
Incorrect. The ordered steps for how bias can lead to racial profiling:

  1. Stereotype: Negative stereotypes are present in society about racialized or Indigenous Peoples (such as, criminality, trustworthiness, credibility or intelligence), which are reinforced by explicit or implicit messages from the media
  2. Unconscious bias: Our brain, over time, makes an unconscious automatic association between the group of people and the stereotype
  3. Activating situation: Especially when in a new or unfamiliar situation, the unconscious bias can activate and we treat the individual as if they fit the stereotype  
  4. Differential treatment: These automatic associations can then, without us being conscious of it, influence how we react to and interact with this person, sometimes resulting in discriminatory behaviour

title: What can we do to disrupt our biases?
displayTitle: What can we do to disrupt our biases?
body:
Unconscious biases are difficult to deal with because we do not know they are influencing us. However, there are everyday actions we can take to disrupt unconscious bias and limit its effects on our understanding, actions and decisions. In recognition that our biases can muddy our thinking when we are under pressure, in 2011 the Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department developed a new policy to address this. An officer in a foot pursuit would no longer put hands on the person fleeing if possible. It was up to the officer’s backup, usually right behind, to make the arrest. Running after a suspect pumps the pursuing officer with adrenaline and stress, both of which allow unconscious bias to impair decision-making. The Las Vegas policy allows the more cool-headed officers to arrest the suspect as their biases are less heightened. The use of force incidents fell 23% in the year after the policy was established.

[Reference: 19]

Serving travellers in a non-discriminatory way is fundamental to our values at the CBSA – and to our success as BSOs. 

This is the second of three modules in this course.

title: Learning objectives
body:
In this module you will learn about:

  • A BSO’s obligations to carry out their duties in a non-discriminatory way
  • The distinction between an inclusive and discriminatory approach
  • Best practices and considerations from the law to support us in carrying out our duties with professionalism, integrity and respect

title: Is racial profiling an effective tool?
displayTitle: Is racial profiling an effective tool?
body:
Racial profiling has been shown to be neither an effective nor an efficient law enforcement strategy. There is no racial or religious profile for people who conduct illegal activity. In fact, focusing predominantly on a specific racial profile could lead to overlooking a traveller that does not match the given profile. It can also result in many innocent people being questioned for little reason other than the colour of their skin, religious dress, or country on their passport, for example. This can alienate communities we rely on for support and to whom we have an obligation to protect - and can undermine the legitimacy of our work.

[References: 1, 7]
instruction: Select each pin to learn about how both US Customs and police forces in the UK improved their results by eliminating racial profiling.

_items.title: Example: US Customs
_items.body:
When race was used as a determining factor:

  • 43% of searches were performed on Black and Latino people - a far higher rate than their proportion as travellers.
  • A large number of searches, including invasive x-rays and strip searches, were carried out on Latina and Black women suspected of being ‘drug mules’, based on a profile that relied heavily on nationality and ethnicity.  

Results:  

The ”hit” rates for these searches were low across all groups:

  • 5.8% for White people
  • 5.9% for Black people
  • 1.4% for Latino people  

It was particularly low for Black and Latina women, who were the least likely to be carrying drugs.  

When the focus was shifted to using behavioural profiles:

  • US Customs changed its procedures, removing race from factors to consider in making stops.
  • It introduced observational techniques focusing on behaviours such as nervousness and inconsistencies in passenger explanations, using more intelligence information, and requiring closer supervision of stop and search decisions.    

Results:  

  • The number of searches carried out dropped by 75%.
  • The hit rate improved from just under 5% to over 13% and became almost even for all groups.

[Source: Harris (2002), US Customs Service (1998), referenced in European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (2010).  Towards More Effective Policing, Understanding and preventing discriminatory ethnic profiling: A guide. European Union.]

_items.title: Example: UK Police Forces
_items.body:
The issue:

A 2010 report called "Stop and Think" by the UK Equality and Human Rights Commission showed that in comparison to White people:

  • Black people were six times more likely to be stopped and searched by the police
  • Asian people were stopped and searched twice as often    

Actions taken:

Five major police forces implemented an 18-month program to:

  • promote intelligence-led stops and searches, rather than officers relying on hunches or generalizations about groups of people
  • eliminate the use of performance targets and monitoring of race patterns    

Results: 

  • In all five police forces, use of stop and search was cut by up to 50%
  • In four of the five forces, the disproportionate use of stop and search with racialized people was reduced, demonstrating a fairer and more efficient use of these powers
  • In all five forces, the "hit rate", or rate of detections and arrests, rose, despite fewer searches on the street

title: Introduction
body:
As Border Services Officers (BSOs), treating all people with respect, dignity and fairness is fundamental to our relationship with the Canadian public. A key part of this is serving all travellers in a non-discriminatory way. This course will build your knowledge and skills to help you achieve these goals on the job.

Audience

  • Distinguish between appropriate and discriminatory approaches to serving the public
  • Apply strategies to support conscious, consistent and bias-neutral application of Agency policies and procedures.

 

Duration

title: What is racial profiling?
body:
Racial profiling is an action:

  • carried out by people in authority or by an organization
  • done for reasons of safety, security or public protection
     

It is based on stereotypes about a person’s:

  • race
  • colour
  • national or ethnic origin
  • religion
     

It is not based on factual grounds or reasonable suspicion singling out an individual or group for greater scrutiny or differential treatment.

 

[CBSA Directive on Non-Discriminatory Treatment]

title: Why is racial profiling training important for BSOs?
displayTitle: Why is racial profiling training important for BSOs?
body:
As mentioned in module 1, negative stereotypes about racialized and Indigenous Peoples are prevalent across society and in our institutions. These stereotypes are powerful and none of us are immune to their influence – either consciously or unconsciously. Racial profiling is a complex topic – not being clear on what it is, how it can happen and the role we can play in preventing it could lead some to be cautious when interacting with travellers.

This training will develop your awareness and skills on the topic of racial profiling, so you are more confident to fully engage with travellers from all backgrounds in an inclusive way. This, in turn, supports the CBSA to build and maintain the trust of the public and communities we serve.

Racial profiling training:

  • builds the confidence of BSOs to serve travellers in a non-discriminatory way
  • builds awareness that racial profiling can be intentional – but can also happen unintentionally
  • helps the CBSA maintain the trust and cooperation of travellers and communities

title: How can we exercise our authority appropriately?
displayTitle: How can we exercise our authority appropriately?
body:
As BSOs, we have comprehensive and robust protocols in place to guide the decisions we make every day on the front lines. These protocols support us to demonstrate our values when enforcing the laws of Canada. 

We often need to read between the lines and use our discretion in determining the best course of action in sometimes unclear situations. We draw on our training, experience, intelligence-based indicators, and our knowledge of the law to make our best judgement.

Discretion allows us the flexibility needed to do our jobs quickly and efficiently. However, in line with our values, we have a responsibility to exercise this power fairly – while recognizing, respecting and valuing each person’s differences. 

We must use our discretion appropriately to ensure that all persons, including Canadian citizens, seeking entry to Canada are subject to the same rules and regulations – regardless of race, colour, national or ethnic origin, religion.

[References: 9, 14, 16]

title: How can we build public confidence in our inclusive approach?
displayTitle: How can we build public confidence in our inclusive approach?
body:
It is not only racialized and Indigenous communities that are stereotyped and experience the adverse effects of unconscious bias. Members of these communities as well as the wider public we serve may also hold biases about us, based on past experiences with the wider law enforcement profession and media coverage. Serving travellers in an inclusive way presents an opportunity to dispel theses myths and build public confidence and trust in our legitimacy. It is important to leave each traveller feeling that they have received fair treatment. This can help improve community relations with our organization, and support ongoing cooperation with our activities.

Communicate in a transparent way by:

  • Demonstrating a respectful attitude throughout the interaction
  • Providing a valid reason for why you are engaging in a particular course of action (including any additional searches or investigations)
  • Thanking them for their cooperation
  • Focusing on resolving any issues that arise - and maintaining a professional approach, even if an individual becomes agitated or upset

title: What are the benefits for the CBSA of providing bias-neutral service?
displayTitle: What are the benefits for the CBSA of providing bias-neutral service?
body:
As mentioned, our brains have developed unconscious biases to help us quickly interpret the complex world around us. We cannot eliminate this process, but we can work to limit its effects by carrying out our duties as BSOs in a bias-neutral way. This means that we make decisions and take actions based on fact - not biases or personal opinions.

Providing bias-neutral service will help us do our jobs better in several important ways:

  • Safety: By not focusing efforts on select groups of people, we take a more conscientious approach to ensuring the safety and security of Canada
  • Relationship-building: By communicating transparently with travellers, we help strengthen mutual understanding and partnerships with the communities we serve
  • Decision-making: By challenging stereotypes, we apply our protocols more fairly, accurately and objectively
  • Organizational legitimacy: By helping Canadians and visitors rest assured that they will be provided quality service, free from any form of discrimination, we build respect for our work

We’ve developed our biases over the course of our lifetimes, so it will require motivation and persistence to manage them to achieve better outcomes for all.

For everyone seeking to enter the country, we are the first face they see. We have both an important responsibility and a tremendous opportunity to welcome the world to Canada.

As BSOs we are up to the task.

title: What is racism?
body:
As we’ve seen, race is a socially constructed way of judging, categorizing and creating difference among people.  Despite the fact that there are no biological races,  race is a powerful force with real consequences for people. 

Two important effects to be aware of are racism and racial discrimination. 

Let’s check to see what you know already  

Everyday racism can be subtle, but its cumulative effect can be profound – it can be experienced through:

 

 

[References: 11, 13]

Glances: An employee displaying disapproving glances at a co-worker wearing traditional dress to the office

title: What is racial discrimination?
body:
An explicit form of racial discrimination is racial harassment - such as comments, jokes, name-calling, or a display of pictures or behaviour that insults or offends based on an individual’s race. Racial discrimination can also take more subtle and less obvious forms.

[References: 11,13]

Employment:
  • Failing to hire, train, mentor or promote a racialized person
  • Subjecting an Indigenous person to excessive performance monitoring or more serious consequences for a common mistake

Housing:
  • Turning an Indigenous person away as a tenant
  • Not granting a racialized person equal access to property maintenance and repairs

Services:
  • Questioning a racialized traveller in a more intensive way at the border
  • Treating an Indigenous traveller in an unprofessional way, such as dumping out their baggage during a search

_feedback.title: Feedback: What is racial discrimination?
_feedback.correct:
The illegal expression of racism – it is addressed under the Canadian Human Rights Act (CHRA):

  • Includes any action or decision that treats a person or a group negatively based on race
  • People in Canada are protected from this by the CHRA when they are employed or receive services from the federal government
  • Often, race only needs to be one factor in a situation for it to have occurred – other factors that also indicate racial discrimination include colour, national or ethnic origin or religion
  • One form it can take is racial profiling

title: How does the context of racism affect experiences of racial profiling?
displayTitle: How does the context of racism affect experiences of racial profiling?
body:
The legacy of racism in Canada is evident in our systems and structures. Some of the groups most vulnerable to racial profiling today have also historically experienced racial discrimination. This can compound how strongly people may react when they receive – or perceive that they are receiving – discriminatory treatment. Similar strong reactions can be expressed if the person affected arrives to Canada from a country with repressive governments or law enforcement systems. Being profiled can trigger memories of the system that they have left behind. Let’s review the historical timeline of racism in Canada to gain a deeper understanding of the context for members of racialized and Indigenous communities.

Select each date range on the timeline to learn more.

[Reference: 13]

_items.body: The Indian Act gave the federal government control over “Indian” political structures, landholding patterns, resource and economic development and almost every important aspect of Indigenous Peoples’ lives. This included prohibiting land ownership, denial of the right to vote, prohibiting leaving reserves without a pass, preventing ceremonial festivals and events, and determining who was an “Indian”.

_items.title: 1870s-1990s:
_items.body: Indigenous children were forcibly removed from their homes and communities and sent to residential schools operated by missionary societies. Here, they were forbidden to speak their language, practice their traditions and customs and to learn about their history. Many experienced malnutrition, overcrowding, illness, harsh discipline and sexual abuse.
Under the Chinese Immigration Act, drafted to restrict and regulate immigration from China, Chinese people had to pay $50 (later raised to $100, and then $500) to enter Canada.

_items.title: 1850s-1960s:
_items.body: Many African Canadians were excluded from schools, churches, restaurants, hospitals and public transportation. They were restricted to menial, low-paying and exhausting labour. Many lived in segregated communities in Nova Scotia, New Brunswick and Ontario. The Ontario legislature established segregated schools, which remained in place up to the mid-1960s.

During the Second World War, 23,000 Japanese-Canadians living on the West coast of British Columbia were sent to relocation and detention camps in isolated areas in the interior of British Columbia, Southern Alberta, Manitoba and Northern Ontario in the name of "national security".

title: What are the risks of racial profiling for the CBSA?
displayTitle: What are the risks of racial profiling for the CBSA?
body:
Racial profiling – or perceptions of it - can lead to:

  • A lack of confidence by society of the fairness of procedures
  • Negative impact on the morale of racialized and Indigenous employees
  • Unwillingness of affected community members to seek a career in the organization
  • Undermining of the legitimacy of the CBSA

In addition to the huge toll racial profiling takes on individuals, families and communities, it can have significant negative impacts for any organization that practices it - or is perceived to do so.  

As a public institution, the CBSA is committed to carrying out our mandate and enforcing the laws of Canada with impartiality and fairness. Doing so also encourages citizens to work positively and cooperatively with us to help us be successful.  

The CBSA has developed this course to support BSOs to build awareness, knowledge and skills to prevent racial profiling, and avoid some of the risks associated with this harmful phenomenon.

Taking this module and the next two will support you to serve all travellers with professionalism, integrity, and respect.

title: What are the impacts of racial profiling?
displayTitle: What are the impacts of racial profiling?
body:
• Overrepresentation of Black and Indigenous children in child welfare
  • Harsher sentences for Indigenous Peoples in the criminal justice system
  • Higher incidences of traffic stops for racialized people
  • Over-scrutinization of Muslim people on public transportation
  • Disproportionate discipline of racialized students in the education system
  • Heightened scrutiny and surveillance of Muslims, Arabs and West Asian people at borders

What impact can these experiences have on those affected? 

If you have never experienced racial profiling or do not know someone who has, it may seem to be nothing more than an inconvenience. However, the act of racial profiling – and even the perception that it may have occurred – can have a range of severe impacts on racialized and Indigenous Peoples. Those who experience profiling can be affected emotionally, psychologically, and in some cases even financially and physically. Effects are also felt within families, in communities and in broader society. 

[References: 2, 12, 16]
instruction: Select and explore the profile to learn more.

_items.title: Individuals, families and communities:
_items.body:
Physical, psychological and behavioural impacts:

  • Embarrassment, disappointment, anger, helplessness
  • Diminished self-esteem and self-worth
  • Stress, insomnia, depression, Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
  • Legal costs to defend against charges
  • Criminal record, affecting employment opportunities

Trust in police, the law and society:

  • Mistrust of public institutions
  • Constant expectation of unfair treatment
  • Fear for own safety when interacting with institutions
  • Feelings of alienation and a diminished sense of belonging
  • Failure to use available community resources and institutions, leading to a loss of opportunities

_items.title: Broader society:
_items.body:
• Confirmation of feelings of racism
  • Perceptions of race-related threats

title: About: The experience of being profiled
displayTitle: About: The experience of being profiled
body:
People are profiled based on stereotypes, and stereotypes exist about all kinds of groups of people. Take a moment to think about some of the negative stereotypes present in society about law enforcement – “Law enforcement officers are …”.  

Now, consider the following scenario.  

You are on duty in a major Canadian airport walking from one terminal to another to process a group of arriving travellers. On your way to the other terminal someone passing by looks at your uniform and shouts in your direction: “Hey, you guys are… (recall the stereotype that came to mind).”
You would have every reason to feel disturbed or annoyed by the person's comment.
While you would no doubt respond to this situation in a professional manner, you might not come away from the encounter with a favourable impression of that person - who may have challenged the quality and legitimacy of your work, and embarrassed you in front of your co-workers, airport staff, and others.  

The bottom line is that no-one wants to be profiled. People will be rightfully upset and hurt when assumptions are made about them, or when they are suspected of wrongdoing - whether based on race, colour, ethnicity, ancestry, religion, or place of origin, or a combination of these.

title: How can we identify racial profiling?
displayTitle: How can we identify racial profiling?
body:
As we’ve seen, racism can be subtle. As a result, racial profiling is more often proven based on the circumstances of a situation, rather than on direct evidence. In simpler terms, this would be the case if the person who allegedly profiled has:

  1. Had an opportunity to observe or presume the race of the individual affected; AND
  2. That this knowledge led the person who profiled to act in a discriminatory way.
